awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: How Accent Distance Impacts Word Recognition Across the Lifespan
awd_abstract_narration:
An increasingly globalized society brings together speakers with many different regional or nonnative accents. These pronunciation differences can pose challenges for successful communication, particularly in children, whose language and cognition are still developing. Indeed, mature perception of speech produced by talkers with unfamiliar dialects and accents does not develop until late adolescence. Understanding how and when these pronunciation differences lead to breakdowns in communication is essential for facilitating communication across people from different cultures, languages, and age groups. This project will result in a better understanding of how specific accent properties and listening situations contribute to children's and adults' ability to communicate across dialects and nonnative accents. 

This project is expected to markedly increase the understanding of how regional dialect and nonnative accent variation impact children's and adult's word identification by characterizing accent distance within the segmental, suprasegmental, and perceptual domains. Establishing reliable and predictive measures of pronunciation distance is a key to bridging work focusing on adults' and children's perception of specific phoneme contrasts and perception of naturally produced sentences of different dialects and accents. This project will establish a quantitative pronunciation distance metric of accent variation. Segmental, suprasegmental, and perceptual distance from the home dialect (Midland American English) for a wide variety of regional dialects and nonnative accents will be measured. The predictive value of the metrics will be assessed for children's and adults' word recognition accuracy in quiet and in noise. The research provides foundational knowledge for a testable word recognition model of unfamiliar accents at key points across the lifespan. Societal benefits resulting from the research include the recruitment and retention of women and individuals from underrepresented groups into research careers, provision of science education to the general public through community engagement and outreach activities, and the sharing of research products including audio recordings, datasets, and experimental code.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
When a speaker has an unfamiliar accent, it can be more difficult to understand them. These unfamiliar accents can be either first language varieties (e.g., a Scottish accent for someone listening from the United States) or second language varieties (e.g., a speaker using English whose first language is Portuguese). In general, these communication challenges can be particularly acute in noisy environments, like a loud restaurant, and for children who are still developing their language skills. However, some individual speakers and specific accents appear to be more challenging to understand than others.

In this project, we evaluated a range of methods for characterizing how a relatively large number of unfamiliar accents differ from the local standard. We then related those methods to listeners’ word identification and to a perceptual measure of how different an accent sounds from the local standard. Several methods used phonetic transcription, a notation system for representing how specific speakers produce speech sounds. The transcriptions for the unfamiliar accents were compared to the local accent and a score was given that represented how different the two productions were. We also tested measures that used the acoustic signal itself to calculate a distance between two accents and speaking rate measures.

We showed that the methods based on phonetic transcription were the best predictors of how difficult listeners found it to understand a talker with an unfamiliar accent, regardless of if it was a first- or second-language variety. The impact of producing words differently than speakers of the local accent on listeners’ understanding became stronger in noisier environments. That is, adults could understand speakers who produce words differently than local speakers in quiet conditions, but showed difficulty as background noise got louder. We also demonstrated that these pronunciation measures related to children’s abilities to understand unfamiliar accents. Children tended to have more difficulty than adults understanding people whose accents were more distinct from the local accent than those with fewer differences, even in quiet, but especially in noisy conditions. Together, these results showed that differences in listeners’ abilities to understand talkers with different accents can be accounted for by measures that quantify phonetic differences from the listener’s local accent.

In addition to the word recognition studies, we also used a task called the ladder task in which listeners ranked audio recordings of speakers representing different first and second language accents based on their distance to the home accent. The results from these experiments showed that children as young as six years are sensitive to differences among accents including both first and second language accents. These results contrast with earlier studies that suggested children weren’t sensitive to differences between different first language accents, although they could tell a second language accent apart from the local accent. Prior results may have arisen due to the complexity of the tasks that other researchers used. Furthermore, the same pronunciation distance metrics that were related to speech understanding also related to perceived distance from the home accent. Again, the transcription-based measures were better than the acoustic measures at predicting perceptual distance. The finding regarding children’s sensitivity to accent distance has critical implications for social interactions, as accent differences can be markers of ingroup vs. out-group status and can lead to bias against speakers with unfamiliar accents. 


The broader impacts of the proposed work were the recruitment and retention of women and individuals from underrepresented groups into research-based career trajectories. Five undergraduate students, all female with two from underrepresented groups, contributed to the research with three of the five either currently applying to or attending graduate school. One PhD student, who is from an underrepresented group, contributed to the project and plans to pursue a career in academia. We provided science education to the general public through engagement with the community at a science museum and in our laboratories where participants could be involved in citizen science and had information about the science of accent perception shared with them. We have shared our research products including recordings, datasets, and experimental code, which are publicly available on the Open Science Framework website, and have published our articles using open-access publishing options.
